description: From Spanish siesta, from Latin sexta (“the sixth hour from dawn, noon, midday”).

entries.meaning: A nap, especially an afternoon one taken after lunch in some cultures.
examples: One humid afternoon a visitor did arrive to disturb Rottcodd as he lay deeply hammocked, for his siesta was broken sharply by a rattling of the door handle  […]

verbs.description: siesta (third-person singular simple present siestas, present participle siestaing, simple past and past participle siestaed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) to take a siesta; to nap.
